items.title: Poland formally withdraws from Ottawa Convention on landmines, citing Russian threat
items.summary_auto: Poland will use anti-personnel as well as anti-tank landmines to defend its eastern border against the growing threat from Russia, Poland's deputy defence minister told The Associated Press on Friday, as the country officially left an international convention banning use of the controversial weapons.

items.title: Researchers warn of negative health outcomes from fracking in the B.C. Peace region
items.summary_auto: Researchers met with City of Dawson Creek council on Feb. 9 to discuss the potential harms and health outcomes of oil and gas activity in northeast B.C. Dr. Ulrike Meyer, a Dawson Creek, B.C. family physician of more than 30 years, said she's seen the prevalence of rare cancers at an alarming frequency, and claims exposure to contaminants from nearby fracking is to blame.

items.title: Ex-worker describes ‘war zone’ at Canadian mining site in Mexico before kidnapping of 10 employees
Alberta Premier Danielle Smith announces fall referendum on immigration, constitutional questions
This tenant’s fight against a renoviction is heading to N.S. Supreme Court
items.summary_auto: Tracey Lothian’s landlord said he was going to renovate the home she was renting and he needed her to move out. She left, but he didn’t carry out the renovations. He brought in a new tenant and raised the rent more than 30 per cent.

items.title: Montreal is mentioned in the Epstein files hundreds of times. Here’s what we know
Gaza doctor says MSF decision to pull out of key hospital leaves staff vulnerable to IDF attack
items.summary_auto: After 20 months of activity in the Gaza Strip, Doctors Without Borders says it's scaling down operations at Nasser Medical Complex after staff reported seeing armed gunmen in the courtyard of the hospital.

items.title: Carney government shifts advertising budget to more patriotic messaging
items.summary_auto: The federal government reallocated its advertising spending budget after Prime Minister Mark Carney's new cabinet was sworn in last year, recently disclosed figures show, shifting its priorities to patriotic and economic messages and purchasing pricey television airtime during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Winter Olympics.

items.title: Glen Powell's How To Make a Killing is good, actually
items.summary_auto: John Patton Ford-directed How To Make a Killing is far from perfect. But the updated, and intentionally depressing, commentary on hustle culture and personal advancement more than warrants a revisit to this often-adapted story.

items.title: Local management had dealings with armed group before kidnapping at Canadian mining company, say ex-workers
items.summary_auto: The on-site management of a Canadian mining company in Mexico whose workers were killed earlier this year had allegedly established some level of co-ordination with an organized armed group in the region, according to a former employee and two ex-contractors.

items.title: Jonathan Haidt says Zuckerberg trial could finally hold Big Tech accountable for the harm done to young users
items.summary_auto: For years, Jonathan Haidt has warned that handing smartphones and social media to kids have caused tremendous harm. Now, he says we could be at a turning point, as Mark Zuckerberg appears before a jury for the first time to defend Meta Platforms against allegations it knowingly targeted young users.

items.title: Skiers killed in California avalanche were close friends, experienced backcountry skiers
items.summary_auto: Six women killed in an avalanche in California's Sierra Nevada were among a group of eight close friends and experienced backcountry skiers on a trip together, their families said in a statement Thursday.

items.title: NASA successfully completes 2nd launch rehearsal of rocket, clearing path for March launch to the Moon
items.summary_auto: NASA is ready to go to the moon. The space agency conducted a successful rehearsal of launch events for the upcoming Artemis II moon mission that will include Canadian Space Agency Jeremy Hansen and NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Christina Koch and Victor Glover.

items.title: Trump claims he'll order agencies to begin releasing records on aliens, UFOs
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump said ‌on Thursday he would direct federal agencies to begin releasing government files related to aliens and unidentified flying objects, citing what he described as strong public interest in the issue.

items.title: Grey's Anatomy star Eric Dane, who went on to be an advocate for ALS awareness, dies at 53
items.summary_auto: Eric Dane, the celebrated actor best known for his roles on Grey's Anatomy and Euphoria and who later in life became advocate for ALS awareness, died Thursday. He was 53.

items.title: Death toll in Gaza far higher in first 15 months of war than reported, new peer-reviewed study says
items.summary_auto: More than 75,000 Palestinians were killed in the first 15 months of Israel's military assault on Gaza, a figure far higher than the 49,000 deaths Gazan health officials ‌announced for that period, according to a new study by The Lancet Global Health medical journal.

items.title: At Issue | Poilievre’s shrinking caucus
items.summary_auto: At Issue this week: Conservative MP Matt Jeneroux walks back his decision to leave politics, but decides to join the other team. The NDP gets closer to choosing its next leader. And Dominic LeBlanc goes on a trade mission to Mexico.

items.title: Canada's public drug plans shouldn't cover new Alzheimer's drug, agency says
items.summary_auto: Public drug plans should not cover lecanemab, a drug to slow early-stage Alzheimer's disease, Canada's Drug Agency says in its draft recommendation.

items.title: NDP leadership candidates debate party's future, relations with provincial wings
items.summary_auto: Five NDP leadership candidates pitched their ideas for how to rebuild their party during what was a fairly agreeable final debate — but some points of contention appeared around relations with provincial wings.

items.title: Youth advocates call on Ottawa to listen to them before tabling new online harms bill
items.summary_auto: Youth advocates are calling on the federal government to treat online safety as a human-rights issue, saying current systems are "not supporting them."

items.title: Federal judge accuses Trump administration of 'terror' against immigrants, vacates ruling on mass detention
items.summary_auto: A U.S. federal judge has thrown out an administrative board's decision endorsing the Trump  administration's policy of subjecting thousands of people arrested during its immigration crackdown to mandatory detention.

items.title: Gordie Howe bridge authority begins search for new CEO following resignation
items.summary_auto: Charl van Niekerk has resigned from the Windsor-Detroit Bridge Authority (WDBA) and has taken up a new position in Toronto, the former CEO confirmed Thursday.

items.title: What we know about the U.S. military buildup near Iran
items.summary_auto: The U.S. has deployed dozens of military aircraft and other assets to bases in and near the Middle East, with President Donald Trump suggesting Thursday strikes against Iran could begin “within 10 days” if a deal is not reached about its nuclear program.

items.title: Montreal hospital recognized for efforts to improve emergency care for seniors
items.summary_auto: The American College of Emergency Physicians is acknowledging St. Mary’s Hospital for its dedication to elder care — a first for a health facility in Montreal. Some of the criteria include how hospitals reduce the risks of infection, delirium and immobility.

items.title: The facts about Cuba in 60 seconds
items.summary_auto: Cuba is in crisis. The U.S. is blocking the country’s oil supply and Cubans are facing shortages of food, medicine and fuel. Here are the facts.

items.title: Banner with Trump's image displayed outside Justice Dept. headquarters
items.summary_auto: A large banner featuring Donald Trump's face was hung on the exterior of the U.S. Justice Department headquarters on Thursday in an apparent display of the Republican president's efforts to exert power over the law enforcement agency that once investigated him.

items.title: 4 extortion investigations launched in Vancouver — the first in the city
items.summary_auto: B.C.’s most populous city is now part of a growing trend of crime where perpetrators threaten residents and businesses with violence in exchange for money.
